title: Synthetic Recap
body:
SACRAMENTO – On a night where the basket must have looked as wide as the ocean, Mitch Richmond authored a performance for the ages, single-handedly carrying the Sacramento Kings to an 86-78 victory over the New York Knicks in 1998.

In a defensive slog where no other player could crack 20 points, Richmond was unstoppable, pouring in a game-high 47 points. He was a one-man offensive system, relentlessly attacking and scoring from all over the floor against a vaunted Knicks defense. While the rest of his team combined for just 39 points, Richmond’s historic output was more than enough to secure the win.

The Kings, fueled entirely by their superstar’s eruption, managed to build a lead that the offensively-challenged Knicks could never surmount. New York’s effort was led by Allan Houston and Larry Johnson, who scored 17 and 16 points respectively, but their combined production paled in comparison to Richmond’s solo act. The Knicks’ offense, typically methodical, was rendered ineffective, shooting a paltry 36% from the field as a team.

Ultimately, this was not a game of strategy or runs, but a testament to one player's transcendent talent. Richmond’s 47 points, an exceptionally high mark that dwarfs all other individual accomplishments from the night, was the entire story. In a grind-it-out contest, he was the undeniable force, delivering a legendary performance that lifted the Kings to victory and etched his name into the annals of franchise history.
